greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Table T read by rows, where T(n, k) is the sum of the largest k primes up to and including prime(n), for 1 <= k <= n.
comment: From the left, the second column gives the sums of two consecutive primes, the third column gives the sums of three consecutive primes, etc. Thus, from the right, the rightmost column gives the running sum of all prime numbers up to that row.

This triangle is the mirror image of A143121: left border are the primes (right border in the other one) while the right border is the sum of the first n primes (A007504, left border in the other one). Row sums are given by A014285, just like the other triangle.
On odd numbered rows, the central entry is exactly the same as the corresponding position in A143121: T(n, (n + 1)/2) = A143121(n, (n + 1)/2). The rest of the row is of course the reverse.
link: Michel Marcus, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..5050 (first 100 rows)
formula: T(n, k) = Sum_{i = n-k+1..n} prime(i), where prime(i) is the i-th prime number.
example: First few rows of triangle are:
T(5, 2) = 18 because the sum of the fourth and fifth primes (two consecutive primes) is 7 + 11 = 18.
T(5, 3) = 23 because the sum of the third, fourth and fifth primes (three consecutive primes) is 5 + 7 + 11 = 23.
mathematica: a[n_, k_] := a[n, k] = Plus@@Prime[Range[n - k + 1, n]]; Column[Table[a[n, k], {n, 15}, {k, n}], Center]
results.author: _Alonso del Arte_, Sep 07 2011
ext: New name from _David A. Corneth_, Aug 31 2020
